description.narrative: The project aims to support the parliament in the four main areas of its constitutional responsibility: lawmaking, setting policy direction, executive oversight, and representation.

title.narrative: 00057935 Strengthening the System of Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia 2014-2016 EU
00057935 Strong Parliament in a Consolidated Democracy 20102013 NETH
Strengthening the System of Parliamentary Democracy in Georgia, II Phase (2016-2018)
RFP: Production of Video Clips and Promotional Materials

description.narrative: Establishing Parliament as a credible institution with greater role in policymaking and EU integration by: (a) improving effectiveness of Parliament; (b) strengthening policymaking and oversight functions; (c) enhancing its role in EU integration
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

Number of implemented IRP goals; Number of implemented OPG commitments; Evaluations by MPs of the work of IRD and PR Departments; MP induction system; Number of committee action plans and annual reports; Quality of committee conclusions on draft budget and budget execution reports; Quality of Parliament scrutiny of draft legislation, including for harmonized laws; Quality of explanatory notes accompanying the draft legislation; Integrated cross-committee action plan regarding AA/DCFTA; Number of citizens aware and supporting Georgias EU integration agenda.

comment.narrative: Despite achieved progress in parliamentary strengthening in recent years, the Georgian Parliament requires continued support, as there remain a number of areas that need to be addressed. In general terms, the Parliament is yet insufficiently strong vis--vis the Government, particularly visible through a low number of legislative initiatives by Members of Parliament and weak government oversight. Limited knowledge and skills of the Parliament staff result in insufficient services to the MPs. Consequently, technical expertise is frequently unavailable for MPs to scrutinize legislation and initiate draft laws. Budgetary and financial scrutiny by sector committees requires further strengthening. Although Parliament succeeded in developing a number of strategic documents, like IRP and OPG AP, both need to be followed up and operationalized. The Parliament is also faced with the challenge of increasing its role in the European integration process through adequate involvement in the legal harmonization exercise and effective government scrutiny of the AA/DCFTA implementation. MPs and staff lack sufficient knowledge of European issues, which also results in low public awareness on Georgia-EU relations.

M&E framework is developed to monitor the implementation of the Parliament's IRP. At least 50% of OPG AP 2015-2016 commitments are implemented; Special guide on OGP practice for parliamentarians is published; IRD and PR Departments capacities are raised through at least 4 different trainings and workshops; Concept for MP induction program is developed and respective parliamentary departments trained to deliver induction trainings; informational materials for induction trainings are published; Parliament's respective staff is advised on PBB, development of pilot PBBs are launched; Committee Staff Manual is finalized; Needs assessment on parliament's role in EU integration is conducted.

M&E framework to monitor the implementation of the Parliament's IRP has not been developed yet as the Parliament will be updated IRP considering the new realities and challenges as well as the new vision of the newly-elected Parliament. Around 60% of OPG AP 2015-2016 commitments have been implemented; Special guide on OGP practice for parliamentarians has been developed; IRD and PR Departments capacities have been raised through 2 trainings for IRD and 2 trainings and one study visit for PR Department. Concept for MP induction program has been developed and respective parliamentary departments trained to deliver induction trainings; informational materials for induction trainings have been published and distributed to MPs; all three phases of the induction program have been conducted in 2016 and January 2017. Parliament's respective staff has been advised on PBB by the Project's Slovenian consultant and on-job-consultancy is on-going to pilot PBBs in healthcare and legal committees and IRD. Committee Staff Manual has been finalized and after its official presentation in the Parliament (envisaged in April 2017), staff trainings will kick off. Needs assessment on parliament's role in EU integration has been conducted and a baseline study report developed on the role of the Parliament in the implementation of EU-Georgia Association Agreement.

Progress of the implementation of the Institutional Reform Plan (IRP) is assessed and recommendations provided. Amendments to Parliamentary Rules of Procedure (RoP) are initiated. 40% of Open Parliament Georgia Action Plan (2017-2018) is implemented. PBBs are piloted in the select committees and departments. Study visit to Austrian Parliament is organized. Capacity development support to IRD is provided. Parliaments Human Resource Strategy is developed. Strategies and multi-year action plans of beneficiary committees are developed and presented. Work is in progress to support the committees in preparing their annual committee reports. Meetings of committees with different stakeholders is facilitated. Committees are further trained on financial oversight skills. Committee Staff Manual is published and presented. Parliaments action plan on engagement/implementation of EU-Georgia AA is developed and presented. International parliamentary conference dedicated to EU integration issues is organized.

Assessment of the implementation progress of the IRP has moved to 2018 as in 2017 the Parliament was mostly focused on the constitutional reform and is currently undertaking the reform of its Rules of Procedure that will have a great impact on the progress of implementation of IRP goals. The Project has been facilitating the work of the Parliament's working group on the Rules of Procedure and providing high-level international advisory services. With the Parliament's request the Project has engaged in the implementation of another important reform in the Parliament which aims at revising and restructuring the role, mandate and functions of the Parliament's research and analytical services. New induction program for the first-time parliamentarians (over 60 MPs) was implemented. Program-based budgets were piloted in two parliamentary committees and one department; however, due to the parliamentary elections in Austria, the study visit was postponed to early 2018. The Project continued facilitating the work of the Parliament's Permanent Council on Open and Transparent Governance and as a result, a new legislative openness action plan (2017) has been developed and adopted by the Parliament Bureau in May 2017. A number of openness commitments were implemented with the Project support, including adapting Parliaments web-site for Persons with Disabilities (PwDs), developing an accessibility plan of Tbilisi Parliament building for PwDs, providing possibilities of citizen comments to draft legislation on the website. Parliament's mobile application and open data portal are under construction. Amendments to the RoP on e-petitions, e-signatures and providing feedback on citizen comments on draft legislation are finalized and expected to be initiated by the Parliament in the coming months. Following the Project's recommendations on the revision of the mandate/charter of the Parliament's International Relations Department, the new unit on interparliamentary diplomacy was forme

description.narrative: Support the development of an efficient public administration system with a stronger capacity of the government to implement a national development agenda that will strengthen the rule of law and improve conditions for democratic accountability
capital of a political entity

comment.narrative: Georgia has made considerable progress in making its public administration system more effective, efficient, transparent, and citizen-friendly. International partners and donors have supported the Government of Georgia in these efforts. However, challenges persist in the consistent implementation of evidence-based decision making, policy formulation, long-term strategy development, as well as the retention of institutional capacity. In addition, comprehensive internal reforms and the requirements of implementing the Association Agreement/ DCFTA signed with the EU increase transformational pressures on the system.

1.1. The VET colleges in Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi, Bagdadi and Zugdidi University are conducting updated agricultural vocational programmes providing training to current and future farmers. In 2016 32 farmers/students per college were trained based on specialized programmes. In addition, about 342 farmers benefited from short-term trainings, provided as non-formal training courses at the colleges. Those trainings were implemented based on needs assessment and newly introduced first-in-Georgia modular training programmes designed with the support of the Project. 376 farmers got extension consulting from the local extension services. 1.2. The project supported the development of infrastructure in 7 colleges mainly with specialized equipment for agricultural workshops. Project purchased English language labs for the seven partner colleges in order to develop English language skill of the teachers and students using modern technologies. 1.3. 7 colleges (Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi, Bagdadi and Senaki Branch of Zugdidi University) have updated their own strategic plans. The plans contain as well the vision for college-based agriculture extension activities. 2.2. The VET colleges in Ambrolauri, Kachreti, Akhaltsikhe, Telavi, Bagdadi and Zugdidi University (Senaki Branch) are offering updated agricultural programmes. The colleges implemented 8 modular programmes in agriculture starting from 2015. Teachers are undergoing trainings for new program implementation. More than 32 students / college / year are trained. 3.2. Project actively supports the implementation the first phase/piloting of the Work Based Learning Program with the Georgian Farmers Association (GFA). In 2016, 40 students participated in the first phase of the program implemented in two directions cattle and fruit production. 3.3. The establishment of a new National VET council was supported and is operational from 2015. The new National VET council and its thematic working

HCFC Phase-Out Management Plan to ensure sustainable and cost-effective phase-out of HCFC according to the schedule of the Montreal Protocol and respective commitments taken by the state.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Georgia freezes HCFC22 consumption by 2013 to meet 10% and 35% reduction targets in 2015 and 2020 according to the Montreal Protocol targets.

comment.narrative: Country obligation to meet agreed targets for HCFC overall consumption reduction

1. Consumption of HCFC22 reduced and HCFC142b phased out by 2020 and 2016 respectively 2. Improvement of certification system; Streamline ruling legislation, which might include but not limited to introduction of Import Quotas on HCFC22 and equipment containing HCFC22 to avoid boosting of HCFC demand. 3. Trainings for technicians, engineers, customs officers conducted. 4. Awareness rising among general population as well as inside targeted groups to improve the safety, efficiency and productivity refrigeration and air-conditioning systems carried out. 5. Natural refrigerant technologies applied through demonstration projects in the RAC.

Commitments related to ODS consumption reduction are met. Legislation was revised and approved by the Parliament. Capacity of customs officers, technicians of the RAC sector increased through series of training.
Preparation and implementation of the demonstration project in RAC sector, aiming at introduction and support of application of natural refrigerant technologies.

After the transfer of landforest to the Machakhela National Park administration from the Forestry Agency of Achara Autonomous Republic in Autumn 2014 the territory is being managed as the protected area and thus the distance between the MtiralaKintrishi PA complex and the nearest forest habitat PA ie Machakhela NP is less than 6km The national boundary of Georgia and Turkey forms the southern boundary of the Machakhela NP The Jamilil Biosphere Reserve lies also along the border and thus the 3rd zone Transition zone is contiguous with Machakhela NP The Machakhela National Park admisnitration has accepted the legal ownershipmanagement of the for

description.narrative: Extent ha of area surveyed and formally proclaimed and managed as Machakhela National Park IUCN Cat II

comment.narrative: 0 ha
Machakhela National Park covering 8733 ha by yr 2

PA official gazettement completed The Government of Georgia undertook efforts at the project development stage to legally establish the Machakhela NP This was agreed by Parliament in April 2012 Detailed boundary demarcation is currently in progress with the support of the project NP Administration has been established and equipped by the Agency of Protected Areas of Georgia Project has supported initial training of NP Administration staff awareness raising within local communities and establishment of the NP administration local authorities and project coordination group as well as refurbishment of NP temporary office within the Machakhela valley

description.narrative: Level of involvement of communities in the management and governance of the NP

comment.narrative: NA

PublicCivil SocietyCommunity PA Planning and Management Governance Board established with proper representation and involvement of local communities in the planning and management of the Machakhela NP by year 2

The Project Coordination Group established and operating that includes local government and community representatives The primary role of this group is to ensure coordination and information sharing during the next 2 years of intense activities to establish the functional capacity of the NP ie boundary and zoning NP Administration training infrastructure and equipment management plan development etc Its secondary important role includes the creation of a mechanism by which the NP and local stakeholders can constructively interact A study of existing and potential mechanisms for maximising practical and meaningful interaction and collaboration between communities living within the borderline of the NP or support zone and the protected area is to be commissioned in the 2nd half of 2015 The study will guide the project on most viable and feasible structures and mechanisms for ensuring community engagement and role in NP management that will be incorporated into the management planning process in 2016

description.narrative: Machakhela NP boundaries and zonation decided and participatory management plan in existence

comment.narrative: Boundaries only provisionally demarcated and zonation not carried out

Clearly defined and consensually agreed boundaries and zones by yr 2
Consensually agreed Management plan exists by yr 3

The project is well on track to meet the target expected date September 2015 A contract to undertake the detailed demarcation and land classification of the NP was selected in April 2015 by the project in agreement with APA The PA boundary demarcation is ongoing including the collection and inputting all existing cartographic land and field surveys data into GIS The contractor closely liaises and informs local government and communities on the progress during implementation of this task This activity is expected to be completed in September 2015 Additionally a contractor has been selected to undertake a detailed resource inventory of the NP and surrounding area baseline studies of biodiversity traditional use cultural heritage etc which will form the baseline for monitoring development of a zoning plan as well as the initial NP management plan scheduled for 2016 The contractor should start its work in August 2015 and complete by February 2016

description.narrative: Necessary infrastructure investment is made by APA and Achara authorities to establish effective management of the NP

Approx 120000 USD

Both the Agency for Protected Areas and the local municipality have already committed significant resources to the establishment of the NP This includes baseline inputs such as staff basic as well as additional equipment additional used vehicle from APA and as agreed during PPG stage the refurbishment of 4km of the Machakhela valley road by the municipality has been completed during 20142015 project cost around 404000 US

For 2016 CCCD project in Georgia targeted to accomplish the tasks contributing to the identification of needs and definition of scope for the development of environmental information/knowledge management system. To that end the consequent activities planned in each quarter clarified the expectations of the stakeholders over the system and capacities to be developed. In particular in the first quarter: Existing stakeholders involved in the implementation of UNCBD, UNCCD, UNFCC, and their respective roles and responsibilities, including legal mandates as well as institutional overlaps and/or gaps were identified and assessed; Target agencies with responsibilities to manage environmental information were identified and design for the climate change, biodiversity and land related data and information exchange was proposed and agreed. The second quarter was dedicated to the development of and consultations on the concept for the web-based environmental information/knowledge management system; identification of key issues on systemic, institutional and individual levels for the monitoring of trends related to climate change, biodiversity and land and development of recommendations for filling the gaps. The third and fourths quarters were mainly concentrated on identification of and agreeing on datasets and respective indicators to be the part of the web-based system, identification of missing responsibilities for generation of data and information relevant for the monitoring of trends in the climate change, biodiversity and land; investigation of compliance of national legislation with provisions on monitoring obligations under the Rio Conventions and the development of the design of web-based environmental information/knowledge management system; In addition in the fourth quarter relevant data and information kept/produced at non-governmental/academic and private sectors were assessed and the possibilities for the inclusion of the data into the web-based syst

Developed web-based environmental information/knowledge management system for data/information collection, sharing and monitoring related to climate change, biodiversity and land Proposed legal framework for the monitoring and implementation of Rio Conventions Proposed inter-ministerial cooperation mechanisms and procedures

The progress report was submitted to the parliament in Spring 2016 The Action Plan approved by the government on 6 June 2016 The implementation is in progress. 2016 implementation due in March 2017. The Project supported awareness raising activities on human rights, especially on rights of PwDs and personal data protection. The Survey conducted by the Project revealed that awareness on HRs improved significantly since 2012. More than 200 PSDA staff members trained on PDP standards. Together with PDPI the Project implemented a number of awareness activities, including PDP weekends, awareness campaign at high education universities and through social media. The amendments were adopted in June 2016 strengthening the oversight of the parliament on implementation of PDO recommendations.

comment.narrative:
Baseline 1.1/ Tools (guidelines for teachers; assessment tools, practical training materials, learning plan) necessary for introducing modular teaching programs in non-agricultural vocations is not delivered
Baseline 1.2/ Stakeholders in vocational education and employment for selected municipalities of Shida Kartli and Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti (Tsalenjikha, Mestia, Kareli, Khashuri, Nikozi) has never been identified and consequently no capacity building programmes have been conducted.
Baseline 2.1.1/ Concept of mobile VET unit has never been implemented in Georgia, despite existence of remote mountainous areas with limited access to VET services.
Baseline 2.1.2/ Concept of distance learning and e-learning elements is not applied in vocational education in Georgia neither at the legislature nor at the college level.
Baseline 2.1.3/ On-the-job training is not applied in Georgia
Baseline 2.1.4/ Concept of international mobility of vocational education students is not developed for Georgia and consequently, no training programs exist in international mobility of vocational students for teachers and management
Baseline 2.2.1/ Considering that greater majority of municipalities of Georgia currently are not covered by vocational education institutions, National Strategy of Vocational Education development envisages introduction of vocational education programs in secondary schools. Currently there are no secondary schools in Georgia which conduct vocational education programs.
Baseline 2.2.2/ Formalized platform for partnership between vocational education institutions and private sector is non-existent in Georgia
Baseline 3/ Life-Long-Learning (LLL) system in VET is not developed in Georgia.
Baseline 4.1-4.2/ Currently existing Government employment schemes deal with only job seekers and employers ignoring such important players as Government employment services and service providers, which negatively affects employability and productivity of labour force. Besid

Target 2016: 1.1.2/ Guidelines for teachers; assessment tools and practical training materials for modular teaching programs of 3 most demanded vocations developed
1.1.3/ Application of above-mentioned instruments in at least 4 modular teaching programs (Tetnuldi and Lakada colleges) monitored
1.2.1/ Needs assessment of potential stakeholders in vocational education and employment in the Government, Parliament and selected municipalities conducted
1.2.2/ At least 2 capacity-building program developed based on identified institutional needs of stakeholders in vocational education and employment
1.2.3/ At least 2/3 of stakeholders from central and municipal levels trained in managing vocational education and employment programs
2.1.1a/ Mobile VET centre for mountainous municipality of Mestia is established/operational 2.1.1b/ At least 60 people retrained and 100 people consulted by Mestia mobile VET unit
2.1.2/ Schemes of distance learning and e-learning implemented in selected vocational colleges and secondary schools (Tetnuldi and Lakada colleges, Agara and Khashuri schools)
2.1.3a/ Organisational Schemes of on-the-job training developed 2.1.3b/ Organizational schemes of on-the-job training implementing in private enterprises of 4 municipalities (Mestia, Tsalenjiha, Kaerli and Khashuri) covering regions of Shida Kartli and Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti
2.1.4a/ Concept of international mobility of vocational education students developed 2.1.4b/ Training programs in international mobility of students for teachers and management personnel elaborated 2.1.4c/ Training in international mobility of students conducted for teachers and management personnel of at least 2 vocational colleges
2.2.1a/ Teachers of Agara and Khashuri secondary schools trained in delivering retraining courses in 4 most demanded vocations locally and in modular teaching
2.2.1b/ Management personnel of Agara and Khashuri secondary schools trained in vocational education management

1.1.2. Guidelines and assessment instruments were developed for all of 4 vocational education programs selected by the project: Low-voltage electrician, Plumber, Receptionist and Mountain guide.
1.2.1. Discussion of main issues that were identified in result of needs assessment conducted with vocational education and employment policy formation participant focus group representatives, and identification of ways of future cooperation.
1.2.2/The stakeholders training was conducted in August in Mestia Municipality Hall on vocational Education and Employment. Seminar was conducted for local authorities and local company representatives (6 companies, mainly representing hotel management and construction) . Objective of the training: review of main aspects and issues of vocational education policy and employment, developing skills for informed decision policy making; comprehending public-private partnership model essence and meaning in vocational education modular educational program during implementation modular teaching, comprehending main aspects of policy making and current policy in vocational education in Georgia.
1.2.3. Public and private sector representatives 16 (including 11 women) Main issues:
Formation of vocational education and employment policy, stakeholders involved in the policy formation and their roles. Internal and external factors that affect vocational education and employment policy formation. International landmarks of vocational education and employment: European association agreement and processes and obligations that are related to the agreement. Legislative base in relation to vocational education and employment Vocational education reform strategy 2013-2020 and action plan of 2013-2017 European qualification framework and national qualification framework. Labor market and employment policy, ongoing issues and international landmarks Employers problems and opportunity to consider the problems during the policy formation process.

2.1.1b/ At least 60 people retrained and 100 people consulted by Mestia mobile VET center 2.2.1f/ Monitoring of modular teachings programs conducted in Agara and Khashuri secondary schools (at least 2 programs per school) and relevant recommendations produced
4.2/ Employment supporting organizational scheme piloted in selected municipalities of Shida Kartli conflict zone (Nikozi municipality) and Samegrelo-Zemo-Svaneti (Mestia,Tsalenjiha) Indicators of achievement: At least 100 people trained o/w at least 90% trainees acquiring graduation certificates; at least 90% of certified trainees receiving validation from joint commission of labour market institution (employment agencies, employers, etc) and service provider representatives; at least 60% of certified trainees finding long-term employment.
4.5c / At least 75 adults retrained in Mestia and Jvari Vocational colleges introducing new elements of learning (module of practical work experience, etc) with at least 90% of trainees acquiring graduation certificates

2.1.1b/ Total of 100 people (o/w 94 female) were trained and consulted by Mestia mobile VET Centre. 2.2.1f/ Group of Internal Monitors, established in Agara public school and trained with UNDP developed methodology for quality assurance, permanently monitored the general modules of vocational educational programs (English, IT, Entrepreneurship, etc) of state-funded vocational education programs of Low-voltage electrician and Plumber in Agara secondary school. Based on the recommendations provided by monitors the process of learning process implementation was streamlined.
4.2/ Implementation of the employment scheme and identification of the most demanded vocations was conducted by NGO Kutaisi Education Development and Employment Centre (KEDEC) for Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti region and by Association of Business Consulting Organizations of Georgia (ABCO) for Shida Kartli region. As a result 252 job seekers were engaged in the Employment scheme program out of which 204 participated in training,172 were certified and 91(52,9%) employed directly after completion of the training courses. 4.5c / 73 adults were retrained in Mestia and Jvari Vocational colleges introducing new elements of learning (module of practical work experience, etc) with about 80% of trainees acquiring graduation certificates.

comment.narrative: - Change Management Plan and respective Communication Plan is developed - A scoping mission to support the Administration of Government in establishing unified performance tracking and monitoring system was conducted by an international expert on M&E - A thorough analysis of available performance appraisal systems was conducted with six partner ministries with active involvement of local HR experts and respective performance appraisal models best-suited for individual ministries were selected. - Awareness of public servants on new Law on Civil Service is enhanced through provision of trainings for 350 servants complemented with additional awareness raising measures - A baseline study of the current service delivery practices in Georgia was conducted and relevant report produced. - Four research and five CSO grants focusing on three key areas of PAR: policy development, civil service reform and public service delivery were selected and funded as part of the first and second cycles of the research and CSO grants competition.

2) Legal Profession is independent and able contribute to high quality protection of interests of citizens; - 2016-2017 AP of Georgian Bar Association developed - capacity of GBA lawyers enhanced through targeted trainings - New modules and trainers are available for GBA training centre for CLE - International Cooperation of GBA is enhanced 3) ADRs is broadly applied, including in the regions - Draft Law on Mediation is submitted to the Ministry of Justice - Knowledge building on mediation through legal profession and general public - International Conference on Mediation conducted - Knowledge building on Arbitration - Arbitration Glossary prepared and published - 3rd Conference "GIAC arbitration days" conducted

Quality monitoring standards for civil/administrative cases drafted Targeted trainings identified by training needs assessment survey conducted A plan for the adaptation of LAS offices for PWDs adopted. Recommendations for the creation of effective Legal Referral System drafted; Electronic Platform for Free Legal Aid Providers created. Based on survey results awareness raising strategy prepared. Activities envisaged by GBA 2017-2018 Action Plan supported. 3) ADRs is broadly applied, including in the regions Law on Mediation Adopted. The Code of Ethics for Mediators adopted. At least 15 Judges trained in referral skills to mediation in cooperation with the HSoJ. At least 15 Judges trained in arbitration. At least 240 lawyers (out of which up to 200 lawyers from regions including lawyers of LAS trained in basics of mediation. description.narrative: Study and Research on Election Media Coverage for the 2017 Local Government Elections in Georgia-Media Monitoring for Local Elections
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

Election media reporting improved in line with election standards and independence of media enhanced in comparison to previous years; - Quantitative indicators revealed as a result of the MM reflecting the dynamics in terms of balanced and unbiased coverage - Observing the interest and public attitude towards MM through collecting the data including through the already existing website www.mediamonitor.ge - The quality of the products provided by the CSOs

comment.narrative: The baseline actions build upon the activities implemented within the 2016 media monitoring cycle, as well as other monitoring initiatives as mentioned above. More specifically: The media monitoring skills and methods provided to CSOs within the previous project will be applied and utilized more intensively in the proposed action. The network of relations with mass media outlets (TV, internet, print and radio), media associations, international and local civil society organizations (CSOs), and active public groups developed within the previous project will be further enhanced. Findings of the proposed action will be checked against those from the previous round of monitoring and a new set of recommendations will be developed. Media rating research implemented within the previous projects will serve as a baseline for new inquiries in the media landscape assessments. Increased risk of political pressure on local journalists and media outlets in the run up to local government elections of 2017. The allegations that the practices of pressure over the media have increased. The polarization seems to be rising. Specific methodology and criteria exist to analyse news, political and elections related talk shows. However, they are not in use as the MM is not ongoing.

-Advanced MM capacities in place with MM results available for structured debates for 2017 Local Self-Governance Elections -Key media sources monitored prior-, during and immediately after 2017 Local Self-Government Elections - The quantitative and qualitative data reflecting the performance of Georgian media in particular during 2017 Local Self Government Elections and showing the latest state of media in general.
